awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Trust-based Access Control Management Framework for Secure Information Sharing and Multimedia Workflows in Heterogeneous Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
[IIS-0545912] 
James B. D. Joshi <jjoshi@mail.sis.pitt.edu> 
University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh 

A Trust-based Access Control Management Framework for Secure Information Sharing and Multimedia Workflows in Heterogeneous Environments 

The goal of this research is to address the complex security, privacy and digital rights management issues related to the emerging multidomain application (EMA) environments, which are characterized by the convergence of emerging grid, P2P and mobile environments with multimedia and workflow technologies. Such EMA environments show huge potential for efficiently automating workflow processes across heterogeneous administrative domains, and for facilitating unprecedented levels of system interactions and information and resource sharing. In particular, the project takes a holistic approach to synthesizing a solution that combines (i) a comprehensive trust-based, adaptive, content and context based access control and secure interoperation framework to facilitate the interaction of constituent domains in an EMA environment, and (ii) a comprehensive framework for addressing the privacy and digital rights management issues related to sharing of multimedia data and workflows. The research will produce required theory, efficient algorithms, specification languages, negotiation protocols, and analysis and administration tools founded on sound design principles and usability considerations which will be validated in a prototype EMA environment. The results are expected to have direct and long-term impact on developing secure data and resource intensive heterogeneous application environments, and will contribute significantly to current efforts related to the protection of complex systems and infrastructures such as the national and global information grid. The research results will be incorporated into the security curriculum of the University of Pittsburgh, which has been designated a national center of academic excellence in information assurance education, and disseminated through publication venues and the project website (http://www.sis.pitt.edu/~jjoshi/nsfcareer/).

Project Goal: The goal of this research is to address the complex security, privacy and digital rights management issues related to the emerging multidomain application (EMA) environments, which are characterized by the convergence of emerging computing paradigm such as grid/cloud, P2P and mobile environments with multimedia and workflow technologies. The key focus of the proposal is to address issues related to Security, Privacy and Trust.

Publication Summary:  The project has resulted in the publication of 14 Book Chapters, 11 published Journal papers, 7 Journal papers that are being submitted, 38 conference/workshop papers and 2 conference posters. The journal publication venues include ACM TISSEC, IEEE TDSC, Computer & Security. These research publications can be summarized as contributions along the following three categories:

Security (more specifically Access Control): In particular, the focus here has been related to developing access control models for fine-grained security control in single systems as well as multi-systems environments. Several work produced have focused on advanced role based access control models. We have developed advanced Administration models for RBAC, purpose-based RBAC to address privacy issues, advanced RBAC models address for multi-agent co-operation environments, Location and Time Based RBAC model to address security requirements in mobile applications, etc. The project has also produced advanced RBAC models to address issues related to secure interoperation among multiple systems. We have developed Trust-based frameworks. Some of these work have focused on specific domain – for instance, we have employed advanced RBAC and policy based approaches to Grid/Cloud environments, and ontology-based access control models for Social networks. Some work also focus on trust and risk -based access control to address Insider threats.

Privacy: Several work produced address privacy issues in different environments. For instance, access control models developed for Social networks consider privacy requirements.  Some research papers have focused on privacy preserving anonymization techniques for location based services (LBSs) and social networks (SNs) -  we have proposed a spatio-temporal anonymization technique for LBSs, anonymization approaches for Location Based Social Networks, and generic anonymization techniques for preserving original structure of a SN to increase utility of anonymized networks. We have also done vulnerability analysis of the SNs environments to rexpose privacy threats – such as Identity Clone and Mutual Friend Based attacks.

Trust management: We have developed trust-based approaches for various types of environments. This includes a trust based access control framework to address the need to establish trust for cross domain accesses when multiple systems interact or share information. We have developed a trust and reputation based approach to address issues related to cheating and collusion in online environments where the system depends on transactions and feedbacks (negative/positive). We have also developed trust-based approaches to counter Distributed Denial of Services attacks (e.g., through flooding and packet spoofing) in networks.

Students/Research Thesis: The project has produced one PhD thesis and one MS thesis. Two current PhD students will graduate in Summer, 2013 and two more PhD students (one is a female) will graduate by Spring, 2014. Their theses are a result of this project’s research activities.
